greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(1) = 0, a(2n) = 0, and for odd numbers n > 1, a(n) = a(A064989(n)) + [n == 3 (mod 4)].
comment: For odd numbers > 1, iterate the map x -> A064989(x), which shifts every prime in the prime factorization of n one index step towards smaller primes. a(n) counts the numbers of the form 4k+3 encountered until the first number which is even has been reached. This count includes also n itself if it is of the form 4k+3 (A004767).
In other words, locate the position where n is in square array A246278 and moving up by that column, count all numbers of the form 4k+3 before an even number at the top of the column is reached.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..16384
Index entries for sequences computed from indices in prime factorization
formula: a(1) = 0, a(2n) = 0, and for odd numbers n > 1, a(n) = a(A064989(n)) + floor((n mod 4)/3).
Other identities and observations. For n >= 1.
mathematica: a[1] = 0; a[n_] := a[n] = If[EvenQ@ n, 0, a[Times @@ Power[Which[# == 1, 1, # == 2, 1, True, NextPrime[#, -1]] & /@ First@ #, Last@ #] &@ Transpose@ FactorInteger@ n] + Boole[Mod[n, 4] == 3]]; Array[a, 105] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 17 2017 *)
xref: Cf. also A038802 (odd bisection of a(n) + A292374(n)).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Sep 17 2017
